meanings.definition: An official in ancient Rome chosen by the plebeians to protect their interests.
meanings.sent1: The tribune spoke for the common people in ancient Rome.
meanings.sent2: The tribune addressed the concerns of the plebeians.
meanings.sent3: The tribune made sure the voices of the ordinary citizens were heard.
meanings.sent4: In the Senate, he was a tribune of the people, standing up for their rights.
meanings.sent5: The tribune's role was crucial in safeguarding the rights of the plebeians.

meanings.definition: A raised platform or dais from which a speaker addresses an audience.
meanings.sent1: The speaker stood on the tribune to address the crowd.
meanings.sent2: From the tribune, the politician delivered a powerful speech.
meanings.sent3: Standing on the tribune made the speaker feel important.
meanings.sent4: The tribune provided a clear view of the audience for the speaker.
meanings.sent5: The tribune elevated the speaker above the audience, commanding attention.

meanings.definition: A person or thing that upholds or defends a cause or institution.
meanings.sent1: She was a tribune of justice, always fighting for what was right.
meanings.sent2: The tribune of tradition upheld the values of the community.
meanings.sent3: The loyal dog became the tribune of the family's happiness.
meanings.sent4: In her role as a teacher, she was a tribune of knowledge and learning.
meanings.sent5: The old oak tree stood as a tribune of strength and resilience in the forest.
